title: 114_hr68
content: The Act is titled the "Tiffany Joslyn Juvenile Accountability Block Grant Program Reauthorization Act of 2016" and it reauthorizes the Juvenile Accountability Block Grant Program. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include graduated sanctions and incentives, remove certain paragraphs, and update interventions for anti-bullying programs. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include graduated sanctions, incentives, and updated interventions for anti-bullying programs. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include incentives as individualized responses to juvenile offenders' compliance with court orders and case disposition terms. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include incentives for juvenile offenders' compliance with court orders and case disposition terms, such as community service hours, reduced curfew, fewer court appearances, and shorter court-ordered supervision periods. The funding allocation is also adjusted from $350,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2006 through 2009 to $25,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2018 through 2022. "SEC. 1811. GRANT ACCOUNTABILITY." The term 'applicable committees' refers to the Senate and House Committees on the Judiciary. Grants awarded by the Attorney General must adhere to accountability provisions, including an audit requirement for unresolved findings. The Inspector General of the Department of Justice conducts audits of grant recipients to prevent misuse of funds. Recipients with unresolved audit findings are ineligible for grant funds for two years. The Attorney General prioritizes eligible grant applicants without unresolved audit findings in the 3 fiscal years before applying. Improperly awarded grant funds must be reimbursed to the General Fund if received during a 2-year grant ineligibility period. The Attorney General must reimburse erroneously awarded grant funds to the General Fund and recoup costs from the grant recipient. An annual certification is required to confirm completion of audits by the Inspector General and mandatory exclusions. Before awarding a grant, the Attorney General must ensure that all mandatory exclusions and reimbursements have been issued. A list of excluded grant recipients from the previous year must be included. To prevent duplicative grants, the Attorney General compares potential awards to avoid awarding duplicate grants for the same purpose. If duplicate grants are awarded, the Attorney General must report it. The Attorney General must report any duplicate grants awarded to the same applicant for the same purpose, including the total dollar amount and the reason for awarding the duplicates. The Congress encourages the use of best practices for activities funded by grants under part R of title I of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. Amounts made available for the Department of Justice, General Administration to carry out the Juvenile Accountability Block Grant Program should be used effectively. The Attorney General will use up to $25,000,000 annually from the Department of Justice's budget to implement part R of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. The bill aims to amend the Act to reauthorize the Juvenile Accountability Block Grant program.
